definition: Gong Zizhen (1792-1841), Chinese man of letters, calligrapher and poet
surname Gong
self/oneself/from/since/naturally/surely
variant of 珍[zhen1]
precious thing/treasure/culinary delicacy/rare/valuable/to value highly

sentences.english: This article chiefly discusses the relationship between Gong Zizhen' s poems and his personality in three sections.
sentences.chinese: 本文分三部分来论述龚自珍诗与人格的关系。

sentences.english: Dickens was contemporary with Gong Zizheng.
sentences.chinese: 狄更斯和龚自珍同时代。

sentences.english: The philosophy of Gong Zizhen marked the beginning of the Chinese modern philosophy.
sentences.chinese: 龚自珍的哲学是中国近代哲学的开端。

sentences.english: While outlining this process, the authors disclose his above poems characteristic of the masculine discourse.
sentences.chinese: 同时也揭示出龚自珍这些诗词的男性话语性质。

sentences.english: Gong Zizhen is a person with both "jian-qi" and "xiao-xin".
sentences.chinese: 龚自珍是个“剑气”与“箫心”兼具的人。

sentences.english: GongZizhen's Poems characteristic of sorrowful– complaint and profound.
sentences.chinese: 龚自珍诗歌在创作上具有悲怨深邃的艺术特色。

definition: Hong Liangji (1746-1809), poet and historian
Wang Shizhen (1634-1711), early Qing poet
Wang Guowei (1877-1927), noted scholar
Gu Yanwu (1613-1682), late Ming and early Qing Confucian philosopher, linguist and historian, played a founding role in phonology of early Chinese, author of Rizhilu or Record of daily study 日知錄|日知录
Yuan Mei (1716-1798), famous Qing poet and critic, one of Three great poets of the Qianlong era 乾嘉三大家
Huang Zunxian (1848-1905), Qing dynasty poet and diplomat, author of A Record of Japan 日本國誌|日本国志[Ri4 ben3 Guo2 zhi4], an extended analysis of Meiji Japan
Nalan Xingde (1655-1685), Manchu ethnic Qing dynasty poet
Li Shangyin (c. 813-858), Tang poet
Wang Fuzhi (1619-1692), wide-ranging scholar of the Ming-Qing transition
Zhao Yi (1727-1814), Qing dynasty poet and historian, one of Three great poets of the Qianlong era 乾嘉三大家
Wei Yuan (1794-1857), Qing dynasty thinker, historian and scholar
Liu Yuxi (772-842), Tang poet
Lin Shu (1852-1924), writer and influential translator and adaptor of vast swathes of Western literature into Classical Chinese

Su Shi (1037-1101), also known as Su Dongpo 蘇東坡|苏东坡[Su1 Dong1 po1] northern Song Dynasty writer and calligrapher/one of the Three Su father and sons 三蘇|三苏[San1 Su1] and one of the Eight Giants of Tang and Song Prose 唐宋八大家[Tang2 Song4 Ba1 Da4 jia1]
Liang Qichao (1873-1929), influential journalist and a leader of the failed reform movement of 1898
Ji Yun (1724-1805), Qing Dynasty writer, author of supernatural novel Notes on a Minutely Observed Thatched Hut 閱微草堂筆記|阅微草堂笔记
